title: Cluster Dose Prediction in Carbon Ion Therapy: Using Transfer Learning from a Pretrained Dose Prediction U-Net
summary:
The cluster dose concept offers an alternative to the radiobiological
effectiveness (RBE)-based model for describing radiation-induced biological
effects. This study examines the application of a neural network to predict
cluster dose distributions, with the goal of replacing the computationally
int...

title: Dissecting Role Cognition in Medical LLMs via Neuronal Ablation
summary: This study investigated whether role prompts in medical Large Language Models (LLMs) induce distinct, role-specific cognitive processes or merely alter linguistic style. Employing the RP-Neuron-Activated Evaluation Framework, neuron ablation, and representation analysis on medical QA datasets, the researchers found that role prompts primarily affect surface-level linguistic features. Critically, these prompts did not enhance medical reasoning abilities, create differentiated cognitive pathways, or alter the core decision-making mechanisms of the LLMs, indicating a failure to replicate genuine cognitive complexity.

title: Pearl: A Foundation Model for Placing Every Atom in the Right Location
summary: Pearl is a novel foundation model designed to accurately predict the three-dimensional structures of protein-ligand complexes, addressing key limitations in computational drug discovery. It achieves state-of-the-art performance by leveraging large-scale synthetic data, an SO(3)-equivariant diffusion architecture, and controllable inference mechanisms. The model significantly outperforms existing methods, including AlphaFold 3, on major benchmarks, promising to accelerate therapeutic design.

title: Evolving Diagnostic Agents in a Virtual Clinical Environment
summary: This paper introduces a novel framework for training large language models (LLMs) as interactive diagnostic agents using reinforcement learning, enabling them to manage multi-turn diagnostic processes and adaptively select examinations. Leveraging a virtual clinical environment (DiagGym) and a new benchmark (DiagBench), the developed DiagAgent significantly outperforms state-of-the-art LLMs in diagnostic accuracy and the quality of examination recommendations. The findings highlight that learning diagnostic policies through interactive exploration and outcome-based feedback confers superior, clinically meaningful diagnostic management abilities compared to passive training approaches.

title: Eye-Tracking, Mouse Tracking, Stimulus Tracking,and Decision-Making Datasets in Digital Pathology
summary: This paper introduces PathoGaze1.0, a novel and comprehensive behavioral dataset designed to analyze and understand diagnostic errors and inconsistencies in digital pathology. It captures dynamic visual search and decision-making processes from pathologists interpreting giga-pixel whole-slide images (WSIs) during cancer diagnosis, aiming to improve human training and AI system development.

title: Learning to generalize in evolution through annealed population heterogeneity
summary: This paper demonstrates that annealed population heterogeneity, where distinct individuals experience varying environmental conditions over time, acts as an implicit regularizer to bias evolutionary systems towards generalist solutions. This mechanism, mathematically analogous to a variant of mini-batching in stochastic gradient descent, introduces a variance-weighted demographic noise that promotes generalization crucial for anticipating future environmental changes and developing robust adaptive strategies.

title: Generative AI for Healthcare: Fundamentals, Challenges, and Perspectives
summary: This paper proposes a data-centric paradigm for the design and deployment of Generative AI (GenAI) systems in healthcare, addressing the need for robust data infrastructure amidst GenAI's transformative potential. It introduces a foundational medical data ecosystem to sustainably integrate, represent, and retrieve diverse medical data and knowledge, enabling high-quality GenAI operations from model training to clinical applications.

title: Local Performance vs. Out-of-Distribution Generalization: An Empirical Analysis of Personalized Federated Learning in Heterogeneous Data Environments
summary: This study addresses the critical trade-off in Federated Learning (FL) between optimizing for local model performance (as in Personalized Federated Learning, PFL) and ensuring robust out-of-distribution (OOD) generalization. The authors propose and evaluate Federated Learning with Individualized Updates (FLIU), a modified FedAvg, empirically comparing various FL approaches on both metrics across diverse data heterogeneity levels to achieve a nuanced understanding of their capabilities.

title: MIMIC-Sepsis: A Curated Benchmark for Modeling and Learning from Sepsis Trajectories in the ICU
summary: MIMIC-Sepsis introduces a carefully curated benchmark dataset and framework derived from MIMIC-IV, specifically designed for reproducible modeling of sepsis trajectories in Intensive Care Units (ICUs). It addresses limitations of existing research by providing time-aligned clinical and comprehensive treatment data for 35,239 patients, demonstrating that incorporating treatment variables significantly enhances predictive model performance, particularly for Transformer architectures.

title: Methodology for Comparing Machine Learning Algorithms for Survival Analysis
summary: This study presents a comparative methodological analysis of six machine learning models for survival analysis (MLSA) using a large dataset of nearly 45,000 colorectal cancer patients. It identified XGBoost-AFT as the best-performing model for predicting patient survival while accounting for censored data. The research highlights the significant potential of MLSA to enhance prognostic accuracy and support clinical decision-making in oncology.

title: Can LLMs Write Faithfully? An Agent-Based Evaluation of LLM-generated Islamic Content
summary: This computer science research evaluates the faithfulness and reliability of GPT-4o, Ansari AI, and Fanar in generating Islamic content, addressing risks like misquoting and misapplying religious texts. Using a novel dual-agent evaluation framework, the study found that while models showed relatively strong performance (GPT-4o highest quantitatively, Ansari AI qualitatively), they consistently fall short in reliably producing accurate content and citations—a critical requirement for faith-sensitive and other high-stakes domains like medicine.

title: Unsupervised Detection of Post-Stroke Brain Abnormalities
summary: This paper evaluates REFLECT, a flow-based generative model, for unsupervised detection of both focal lesions and secondary non-lesional structural brain abnormalities post-stroke. The study demonstrates that training the model on fully healthy anatomy significantly improves its ability to segment lesions (Dice = 0.37) and detect non-lesional abnormalities (FROC = 0.62) compared to training on lesion-free stroke slices. This approach aims to better capture crucial imaging biomarkers for post-stroke recovery and outcome.

title: When are radiology reports useful for training medical image classifiers?
summary: This paper systematically investigates how radiology reports, rich with expert annotations, can be leveraged during machine learning model training to improve image-only classification for medical tasks. It analyzes report usage during both pre-training and fine-tuning across diagnostic and prognostic tasks, revealing that report utility depends on label-text association and demonstrating the significant, often dominant, impact of fine-tuning with reports.

title: APEX: Approximate-but-exhaustive search for ultra-large combinatorial synthesis libraries
summary: This paper introduces APEX, an approximate-but-exhaustive search protocol designed to overcome the challenges of virtual screening in ultra-large make-on-demand combinatorial synthesis libraries (CSLs) for drug discovery. APEX leverages a neural network surrogate that exploits CSL structure to predict objectives and constraints, enabling full library enumeration on a consumer GPU in under a minute. This allows for the rapid and accurate identification of approximate top-$k$ compounds, outperforming existing virtual screening methods in both retrieval accuracy and runtime.

title: A Luminance-Aware Multi-Scale Network for Polarization Image Fusion with a Multi-Scene Dataset
summary: This paper introduces MLSN, a luminance-aware multi-scale network designed for polarization image fusion, effectively combining S0 and DOLP images to reveal enhanced texture features. The network addresses challenges of complex luminance environments and inherent contrast differences through novel encoder, bottleneck, and decoder modules. It also presents MSP, a new high-quality dataset, and demonstrates that MLSN significantly outperforms state-of-the-art methods in both subjective and objective evaluations across multiple datasets.

title: Stroke Lesion Segmentation in Clinical Workflows: A Modular, Lightweight, and Deployment-Ready Tool
summary: This paper introduces StrokeSeg, a modular and lightweight framework designed to transform high-performing research-grade deep learning models for stroke lesion segmentation into clinically deployable applications. It addresses the deployment challenges of existing frameworks by decoupling components, utilizing efficient runtimes and quantization, and demonstrating equivalent performance to original PyTorch pipelines while offering portability and user-friendly interfaces.

title: Filtering instances and rejecting predictions to obtain reliable models in healthcare
summary: This paper introduces a novel two-step data-centric approach to enhance the reliability of Machine Learning (ML) models, particularly in high-stakes domains like healthcare, by addressing prediction uncertainty. The method involves filtering problematic instances during training using Instance Hardness (IH) and implementing a confidence-based rejection mechanism during inference. Evaluated on real-world healthcare datasets, the approach significantly improves model reliability by retaining only high-confidence predictions while balancing predictive performance and rejection rates.
domains: Predictive Analytics (e.g., disease risk, treatment response)

title: Adaptive Knowledge Transferring with Switching Dual-Student Framework for Semi-Supervised Medical Image Segmentation
summary: This paper introduces a novel switching Dual-Student architecture combined with a Loss-Aware Exponential Moving Average (EMA) strategy to improve semi-supervised medical image segmentation. The framework enhances knowledge transfer and prevents error reinforcement by dynamically selecting the most reliable student and ensuring the teacher absorbs meaningful information. Evaluated on 3D medical image segmentation datasets, it significantly outperforms state-of-the-art semi-supervised methods, achieving higher accuracy under limited supervision.

title: An N-of-1 Artificial Intelligence Ecosystem for Precision Medicine
summary: This paper proposes an N-of-1 Artificial Intelligence Ecosystem designed for precision medicine, addressing the 'average patient fallacy' of current AI models that underperform for individuals with rare conditions, multimorbidity, or underrepresented demographics. It outlines a multi-agent, orchestrated intelligence framework intended to deliver transparent, equitable, and individualized decision support to clinicians.

title: Towards actionable hypotension prediction -- predicting catecholamine therapy initiation in the intensive care unit
summary: This research develops an XGBoost machine learning model to predict the initiation of catecholamine therapy in critically ill ICU patients, offering a more clinically actionable target than traditional fixed MAP threshold predictions. Utilizing the MIMIC-III database, the model achieved a high AUROC of 0.822, significantly outperforming a MAP < 65 mmHg baseline, by integrating MAP dynamics, treatment context, and patient characteristics to provide proactive decision support. This approach marks a shift towards predictive tools that align with actual clinical decision-making for hypotension management.

title: Forecasting precipitation in the Arctic using probabilistic machine learning informed by causal climate drivers
summary: This study proposes a probabilistic machine learning framework to accurately forecast precipitation dynamics and severity in Arctic maritime environments, addressing climate risk and early warning system needs. It integrates causal analysis of atmospheric drivers with robust forecasting models and uncertainty quantification to enhance prediction reliability and interpretability.

title: Towards Transparent Reasoning: What Drives Faithfulness in Large Language Models?
summary: This paper investigates factors influencing the faithfulness of Large Language Model (LLM) explanations, a critical concern in healthcare where unfaithful reasoning can lead to unsafe decision support. The research evaluates three LLMs (GPT-4.1-mini, LLaMA 70B, LLaMA 8B) on social bias (BBQ) and medical (MedQA) datasets, manipulating few-shot examples, prompting strategies, and training procedures. Key findings demonstrate that both the quantity and quality of few-shot examples, prompting design, and instruction-tuning significantly impact explanation faithfulness.

title: Closing Gaps: An Imputation Analysis of ICU Vital Signs
summary: This paper addresses the critical issue of missing data in Intensive Care Unit (ICU) vital signs, which hinders the development of accurate clinical prediction models using Machine Learning (ML). The authors introduce an extensible and reusable benchmark comprising 15 imputation and 4 amputation methods, designed for comprehensive comparison on major ICU datasets. The primary goal is to guide researchers in selecting the most accurate imputation techniques to improve clinical prediction model performance and facilitate their translation into clinical practice.
